title: Multi-focus - skin cream use of placebo binomial

content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Consider a study designed to investigate the following claim. An antibacterial skin cream is effective in curing a common skin ailment. Two designs are proposed for the study. Proposal <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="bold">I</mtext></math> Proposal <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="bold">II</mtext></math> Randomly select <math alttext="280" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>280</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from the population of people with the skin ailment to use the antibacterial skin cream each day and observe the number of people cured after six months. Obtain <math alttext="280" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>280</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers from the population of people with the skin ailment. Randomly assign <math alttext="160" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>160</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of the volunteers to use the antibacterial skin cream each day. Assign the remaining <math alttext="120" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>120</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people cured in each group after six months. (a) Give an example of what people assigned to use a placebo in Proposal <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> might be asked to use instead of the antibacterial skin cream. Explain the benefit of a placebo in the context of the study.

(b) For which proposal can the results of the study be generalized to all people who have the skin ailment? Explain, in the context of the study, the characteristic of the proposal that allows for this generalization.

A researcher conducted the study described in Proposal <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math> and estimated the difference in the proportions of people similar to those in the study who would be cured by the two treatments. Assume all conditions for inference were met. The resulting <math alttext="95" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval (Antibacterial Skin Cream minus Placebo) is <math alttext="0.20 plus or minus 0.10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn><mo>Â±</mo><mn>0.10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(c) Does the <math alttext="95" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval provide evidence to support the claim? Justify your answer.

(d) Suppose that the researcher instead decided to compute a <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for the same sample data. Would this change impact your answer in part (c)? Explain your reasoning.

The researcher plans to randomly select people from the study, one at a time and without replacement, to be interviewed. The interviews will continue until <math alttext="15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people who had received the antibacterial skin cream are interviewed. Let the random variable <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the total number of people interviewed.(e) Explain, in the context of the study, why the random variable <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> does not follow a binomial distribution.
